title: Your body's real age

options.label: B
options.text: Breakdown products of white blood cells

options.label: A
options.text: They are replaced with new cells

options.label: C
options.text: They are destroyed and never replaced

title: What you don't know about who you will become

multiple-choice.question: What is the main question that fascinates the psychologist in the transcript?

options.label: C
options.text: Why do people make decisions that their future selves often regret?

options.label: D
options.text: Why do people work hard to lose weight?

multiple-choice.question: According to the psychologist, what is the fundamental misconception that people have about the power of time?

options.label: C
options.text: That the rate of change slows over the human lifespan

options.label: D
options.text: That people overestimate how much they will change in the future

multiple-choice.question: What is the "end of history" illusion, according to the psychologist?

options.label: A
options.text: The idea that people will change more in the future than they have in the past

options.label: B
options.text: The idea that people will change less in the future than they have in the past

options.label: C
options.text: The idea that people will remain the same in the future as they are now

options.label: D
options.text: The idea that people's values and personalities will change drastically in the next 10 years

multiple-choice.question: What did the study on change in people's personal values over time find?

options.label: A
options.text: That people's values change more as they get older

options.label: B
options.text: That people's values change less as they get older

options.label: C
options.text: That people vastly underestimate how much change they will experience over the next 10 years

options.label: D
options.text: That people overestimate how much change they will experience over the next 10 years

multiple-choice.question: What are the five fundamental dimensions of personality, according to psychologists?

options.label: A
options.text: Neuroticism, openness to experience, agreeableness, extraversion, and conscientiousness

options.label: B
options.text: Happiness, sadness, anger, fear, and surprise

options.label: C
options.text: Extraversion, agreeableness, conscientiousness, neuroticism, and creativity

options.label: D
options.text: Openness to experience, agreeableness, extraversion, conscientiousness, and emotional stability

multiple-choice.question: What did the study on personality change find?

options.label: A
options.text: That people's personalities change more as they get older

options.label: B
options.text: That people's personalities change less as they get older

options.label: C
options.text: That people underestimate how much their personalities will change in the next decade

options.label: D
options.text: That people overestimate how much their personalities will change in the next decade

multiple-choice.question: Why do people overpay for the opportunity to indulge their current preferences, according to the psychologist?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they overestimate the stability of their preferences

options.label: B
options.text: Because they underestimate the stability of their preferences

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are willing to pay more for things they enjoy

multiple-choice.question: What is the reason for the "end of history" illusion, according to the psychologist?

options.label: A
options.text: The ease of remembering versus the difficulty of imagining

options.label: B
options.text: The difficulty of remembering versus the ease of imagining

options.label: C
options.text: The lack of information about the future

options.label: D
options.text: The abundance of information about the past

multiple-choice.question: What is the bottom line of the psychologist's talk?

options.label: A
options.text: That people should make decisions based on their current preferences

options.label: B
options.text: That people should make decisions based on their future preferences

options.label: C
options.text: That time is a powerful force that transforms our preferences, values, and personalities

options.label: D
options.text: That people should not make decisions at all

multiple-choice.question: What is the main conclusion of the psychologist's talk?

options.label: A
options.text: That human beings are static and unchanging

options.label: B
options.text: That human beings are works in progress that mistakenly think they're finished

options.label: C
options.text: That people should be more rational in their decision-making

options.label: D
options.text: That people should be less rational in their decision-making

title: What is the biggest single-celled organism? - Murry Gans

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why unicellular organisms cannot grow to be as large as multicellular organisms like elephants or blue whales?

options.label: A
options.text: They lack the necessary nutrients and resources.

options.label: B
options.text: Their surface area and volume increase at different rates, limiting their ability to exchange materials.

options.label: C
options.text: They are unable to undergo cell division.

options.label: D
options.text: They are too simple in structure.

multiple-choice.question: What is the function of the cellular membrane in a cell?

options.label: C
options.text: To act as the doorway into and out of the cell

options.label: B
options.text: It increases by a factor of 10

options.label: C
options.text: It decreases by a factor of 10

multiple-choice.question: What would happen to a huge cell if it were unable to increase its surface area to match its increasing volume?

options.label: C
options.text: It would back up with waste and eventually die

options.label: D
options.text: It would divide into smaller cells

multiple-choice.question: What is an advantage of having multiple small cells instead of a single large cell?

options.label: C
options.text: Greater surface area for material exchange

options.label: D
options.text: Reduced impact of cell damage or death

multiple-choice.question: How do some exceptionally large cells, like neurons, adapt to their size?

options.label: A
options.text: To increase the surface area for material exchange

options.label: B
options.text: To decrease the surface area for material exchange

options.label: B
options.text: It has a simple cell membrane

options.label: C
options.text: It is coenocytic, with multiple nuclei in a single cell

multiple-choice.question: Why is Caulerpa taxifolia able to grow to be relatively large despite being a single-celled organism?

options.label: A
options.text: It has a highly efficient metabolism

options.label: B
options.text: It has a unique frond-like structure that increases its surface area

options.label: C
options.text: It is able to undergo cell division

options.label: D
options.text: It lacks the need for material exchange

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea of the transcript regarding the size of cells and organisms?

options.label: A
options.text: That larger cells are more efficient

options.label: B
options.text: That smaller cells are more limited

options.label: C
options.text: That there are biological limits to the size of cells and organisms

options.label: D
options.text: That multicellular organisms are inferior to single-celled organisms

title: This Video Will Make You Angry

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary way thought germs spread from one brain to another?
According to the analogy, what type of thought germ is a funny cat photo with a perfect caption?
What emotion do thought germs often exploit to spread more effectively?
Why do angry thought germs tend to spread more than other types of thought germs?

options.label: C
options.text: Because they bypass the mental immune system

multiple-choice.question: What is the key point about the Internet's effect on thought germs?

options.label: A
options.text: It helps thought germs die out quickly

options.label: B
options.text: It has no effect on thought germs

options.label: C
options.text: It allows thought germs to spread and change rapidly

options.label: D
options.text: It only spreads accurate thought germs

options.label: A
options.text: They compete with each other for dominance

options.label: B
options.text: They cooperate to reach more brains and hold their thoughts longer

options.label: C
options.text: They have no effect on each other

options.label: A
options.text: They engage in constructive dialogue and come to a resolution

options.label: B
options.text: They mostly argue with themselves about how angry the other group makes them

options.label: C
options.text: They ignore each other and focus on their own issues

options.label: D
options.text: They become more open-minded and willing to listen

multiple-choice.question: Why is it useful to be aware of how thought germs spread and evolve?

options.label: A
options.text: So we can create more effective thought germs

options.label: B
options.text: So we can avoid getting infected with thought germs

options.label: C
options.text: So we can maintain a healthy brain and be cautious of thoughts that have passed through many brains

options.label: D
options.text: So we can ignore the spread of thought germs

multiple-choice.question: What is the main message of the video regarding thought germs and the Internet?

options.label: A
options.text: The Internet is a perfect platform for spreading thought germs, and we should be cautious of how they can use our emotions to spread.

options.label: B
options.text: The Internet has no effect on thought germs, and we should not worry about their spread.

options.label: C
options.text: Thought germs are only beneficial and should be encouraged to spread.

options.label: D
options.text: The Internet is a bad platform for spreading thought germs, and we should avoid using it.
